review.title: Survey:Natural Language Parsing For Indian Languages
review.abstract: Syntactic parsing is a necessary task which is required for NLP applications including machine translation. It is a challenging task to develop a qualitative parser for morphological rich and agglutinative languages. Syntactic analysis is used to understand the grammatical structure of a natural language sentence. It outputs all the grammatical information of each word and its constituent. Also issues related to it help us to understand the language in a more detailed way. This literature survey is groundwork to understand the different parser development for Indian languages and various approaches that are used to develop such tools and techniques. This paper provides a survey of research papers from well known journals and conferences.

metadata.title: Survey:Natural Language Parsing For Indian Languages

sections.text: 1. INTRODUCTIONSyntactic analysis is the process of analyzing and determining the grammatical structure of a sentence in relation to a given formal grammar. Syntactic parsing of a sentence of natural language is considered to be an important intermediate stage of semantic analysis, which can influence many pipelines of the application of natural language processing, such as the extraction of information, word meanings, etc. The study of sentence structure is called syntax. It attempts to describe the grammatical order in a given language in the form of rules that can explain in detail the underlying structure and a transformative process. Syntax provides rules for putting words together to form sentence components and putting these components together to form meaningful sentences. Due to the considerable ambiguity present in human language, the use of which is intended to convey different semantics, it is very difficult to design the underlying structures and a transformative process.

sections.heading: A. Rule Based Parser
sections.text: In a rules-based approach, the language-specific rules are formulated to identify the best parse tree for a given grammar, but in this approach, the production rules are applied recursively, resulting in overlapping, and the problem can be efficiently solved by using Dynamic Programming Techniques (DP). The sub-parse tree cache in the DP-based parsers is referred to as a "chart," and as a result, the DP-based parsers are referred to as "chart parsers." The CYK algorithm and early algorithm are rule-based parsers.

sections.heading: B. Statistical Based Parser
sections.text: Statistical parsers collect statistical data from correctly analyzed sentences and replace ambiguities with experience. The advantage of the statistical approach is that it covers the entire grammar usage of the language. The performance of statistical parsers depends on the training corpus used to collect statistical information about the grammar of the language. Instead of using rules, statistical parsers choose the best parse tree from among possible candidates based on the statistical information. The disadvantage of this approach is that sometimes an invalid sequence of Parse.CFG and parsers based on Probabilistic Context Free Grammar (PCFG) are examples of statistical parsers.

referenceMentions.context: The main challenge is the inherent complexity of linguistic phenomena that makes it difficult to represent the effective features for the target learning models [27].
Statistical parsing techniques are called “data-driven” and rule based parsing techniques are called “grammar-driven” approaches [27].
Joakim Nirve in 2009 [1] presented work to optimize Malt Parser for three Indian languages Hindi, Bangla and Telgu in NLP Tools Contest at ICON 2009.
in 2009 [17] explored two data-driven parsers called Malt and MST on three Indian languages namely Hindi, Bangla and Telugu.
in 2009 [2] proposed a simple parser for Indian languages in a dependency framework.
in 2010[9] describes a data driven dependency parsing approach which uses information about the clauses in a sentence to improve the performance of a parser.
in 2010 [8] analyzes the relative importance of different linguistic features for data-driven dependency parsing of Hindi.

Swati Ramteke et al in 2014[13] developed lexicon Parser for Devanagari script (Hindi), it shows how a Hindi sentence is parsed into tokens and then find the relationship between tokens using grammar and by using semantic representation generate a parse tree.
in 2009 [16] proposed a constraint based Dependency parsing system and applied to a free-word order language Bangla .
in 2009 [4] proposed a dependency parser system for Bengali language.
Akshar Bharati and Rajeev Sangal described a grammar formalism called the ‘Paninian Grammar Framework’ that has been successfully applied to all free word Indian languages [14].
Sagar et al proposed a way of producing context free grammar for the Noun Phrase and Verb Phrase agreement in Kannada Sentences [11].
in 2010 [10] have developed a Penn Treebank based statistical syntactic parsers for Kannada language.
in 2010[15] proposed a Context Free Grammar (CFG) analysis for simple Kannada sentences.
in 2009 [3] have developed a context free grammar for simple Assamese sentences.
in 2014[18] has made an attempt to write context free grammar for simple Marathi sentences.
in 2013[20] presents an efforts towards incorporating external knowledge from Hindi Word Net to aid dependency parsing.
[22] has experimented with different parameters of datadriven Malt Parser along with the two-stage preprocessing approach to build a high quality dependency parser for Hindi.
in 2008 [23] proposed a statistical parsing of Tamil sentences using phrase structure hybrid language model.
in 2008[24] presented a paper is an attempt at exploring and isolating some crucial cues present in the language which lend themselves to robust dependency parsing.
